extractions.description: The paper reviews the search for strong gravitational lenses across different astrophysical sources, lenses, datasets, and wavelengths. It outlines the physical characteristics of lenses and sources, various detection techniques, biases in selection methods, and the future of lens searches in upcoming surveys.

type.justification: The paper primarily reviews existing methods and biases without presenting new empirical data or experiments.
type.quote: Here we review strong lens searches, covering various sources (quasars, galaxies, supernovae, FRBs, GRBs, and GWs), lenses (early- and late-type galaxies, groups, and clusters), datasets (imaging, spectra, and lightcurves), and wavelengths.

name.quote: Machine learning’s first successful applications for lens finding were as late as 2017 (Petrillo et al., 2017; Jacobs et al., 2017; Lanusse et al., 2018), partly due to the advent of wide-field, deep surveys, but also to the requirement of large computational resources associated with the processing of astronomical images.
